https://doi.org/10.7927/hn96-9703.Description: The Shared Socioeconomic Pathways (SSPs) Literature Database v1 (2014-2019) consists of biographic information, abstracts, and analysis of 1360 articles published from 2014 to 2019 that used the SSPs. The database was generated from a Google Scholar search followed by a manual examination of the results for papers that made substantial use of the SSPs. Each paper was then coded along a number of different dimensions, including categories of types of papers or analysis, number of subcategories for SSP Applications and SSP Extensions, particular Shared Socioeconomic Pathways (SSPs) used, particular Representative Concentration Pathways (RCPs) used, and particular SSP-RCP combinations used.

https://doi.org/10.7927/cx02-2587.Description: The Food Insecurity Hotspots Data Set consists of grids at 250-meter (0.25 arc-degree) resolution that identify the level of intensity and frequency of food insecurity over the 10 years between 2009 and 2019, as well as hotspot areas that have experienced consecutive food insecurity events. The gridded data are based on subnational food security analysis provided by FEWS NET (Famine Early Warning Systems Network) in five regions, including Central America and the Caribbean, Central Asia, East Africa, Southern Africa, and West Africa.
https://doi.org/10.7927/cx02-2587.Geographic_Coverage: Central America, Caribbean, Central Asia, East Africa, Southern Africa, West Africa

https://doi.org/10.7927/H49P2ZKM.Description: The Small Area Estimates of Poverty and Inequality dataset provides subnational estimates of poverty and inequality for use in interdisciplinary studies of poverty, inequality, and the environment.

https://doi.org/10.7927/H46M34XX.Description: The Gridded Population of the World (GPW), v4: Basic Demographic Characteristics, Revision 11 dataset provides estimates of population counts by age and sex for the year 2010. These data may be useful in research related to public health, urban infrastructure, and environmental justice.
https://doi.org/10.7927/H46M34XX.Project: GPW - Gridded Population of the World

https://doi.org/10.7927/H40Z716C.Description: The US Census Grids - Summary File 1, 2010 dataset contains grids of demographic and socioeconomic data from the year 2010 in ASCII and GeoTIFF formats. The grids have a resolution of 30 arc-seconds (0.0083 decimal degrees) or approximately 1 square km. The gridded variables are based on census block geography from Census 2010 TIGER/Line Files and census variables (population, households, and housing variables).

https://doi.org/10.7927/H4319SVC.Description: The Global Estimated Net Migration Grids By Decade dataset provides estimates of net migration (in-migration minus out-migration) per one-kilometer grid cell on a decadal basis for the 1970s, 1980s, and 1990s. These data may be useful in urbanization, environmental change, and human migration research.

https://dx.doi.org/10.7927/3xxe-ap97.Description: The Global Gridded Relative Deprivation Index (GRDI) v1: 2010-2020 dataset characterizes the relative levels of multidimensional deprivation and poverty in each 30 arcsecond (approximately 1 km) pixel, where a value of 100 represents the highest level of deprivation and a value of 0 represents the lowest. The dataset was built from sociodemographic and satellite data inputs that were spatially harmonized, indexed, and weighted into six main components to produce the final index raster. Inputs were selected from the best-available data that either continuously vary across space or have at least administrative level 1 (provincial/state) resolution and which have global spatial coverage.

https://doi.org/10.7927/np6p-qe61.Description: The Global Rural-Urban Mapping Project, Version 1: Urban Extent Polygons, Revision 02 dataset provides a polygon representation of urban areas with city or agglomeration name and time series population estimates. These data may be useful in urban flooding research.
https://doi.org/10.7927/np6p-qe61.Project: Global Rural-Urban Mapping Project (GRUMP) - Urban Extents

https://dx.doi.org/10.7927/1z4r-ez63.Description: The Global 1km Downscaled Urban Land Extent Projection and Base Year Grids by SSP Scenarios, v1 data set provides global urban land projections and base year grids based on the Shared Socioeconomic Pathways (SSPs). These data may be useful in urban flooding research.

https://doi.org/10.7927/nj0x-8y67.Description: The Global One-Eighth Degree Urban Land Extent Projection and Base Year Grids by SSP Scenarios, v1 (2000 – 2100) dataset provides global urban land projections and base year grids based on the Shared Socioeconomic Pathways (SSPs) data. These data may be useful in urban flooding research.

https://doi.org/10.7927/0gdn-6y33.Description: The Global Subnational Infant Mortality Rates dataset provides estimates of infant mortality rates for the year 2015. These data may be useful in health, poverty, and environmental studies.

https://dx.doi.org/10.7927/dv72-s254.Description: The Georeferenced U.S. County-Level Population Projections, Total and by Sex, Race, and Age Based on the SSPs, v1 (2020 - 2100) dataset consists of county-level population projection scenarios of total population and by age, sex, and race in five-year intervals for all U.S. counties for the period 2020 - 2100. These data have numerous potential uses and can serve as inputs for addressing questions involving subnational demographic change in the United States in the near, middle, and long-term.

https://doi.org/10.7927/3xxe-ap97.Description: The Global Gridded Relative Deprivation Index (GRDI) dataset characterizes the relative levels of multidimensional deprivation and poverty in each 30 arcsecond (approximately 1 km) pixel, where a value of 100 represents the highest level of deprivation and a value of 0 represents the lowest. The dataset was created using sociodemographic and satellite data inputs that were spatially harmonized, indexed, and weighted into six main components to produce the final index raster. Inputs were selected from the best-available data that either continuously vary across space or have at least administrative level 1 (provincial/state) resolution and which have global spatial coverage.
